title: How Emmanuel Macron can be tracked: Watch the first episode of StravaLeaks
summary: 'StravaLeaks' (1/3). Three of the world's most important leaders have been put in danger due to their security guards' use of a sports social media app, Strava. The first part of our investigation looks into how the French president can be tracked thanks to his bodyguards' love of running.

title: Algeria casts a shadow over the French-Moroccan reunion
summary: On a visit to Rabat starting on Monday, Emmanuel Macron will solemnize the reconciliation with Morocco after a three-year feud, at the cost of a new crisis with Algiers.

title: Egypt proposes two-day Gaza truce in hope of 'a complete ceasefire'
summary: Earlier on Sunday, Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant said 'painful concessions' would be needed in negotiations and that military action alone would not achieve the country's war aims. Out of 251 hostages seized by Palestinian militants during the October 7 attack, 97 are still held in Gaza including 34 the Israeli military says are dead.

title: Georgia elections: Pro-Russian Georgian Dream holds onto power
summary: The electoral commission announced on Sunday morning that Georgian Dream had won with 54% of the vote, despite protests from opposition parties. This will enable billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili to form a government, but risks dashing the country's hopes of joining the European Union.

title: In Japan, the ruling party is about to lose the majority it has held since 2012
summary: Japan's parliamentary elections reveal a weakened Liberal Democratic Party. Diminished by its slush fund scandal and difficulties in taming the country's inflation, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's LDP is likely to embark on a search for new partners for a possible coalition.

title: Lina Khan, the woman making Big Tech tremble
summary: The president of the Federal Trade Commission, America's antitrust agency, is fighting the big monopolies. She irritates Republicans and is participating in the Biden administration's efforts to defend its actions against inflation.

title: Teachers, doctors, civil servants and bankers: Foreign travel of Chinese citizens tightly controlled by CCP
summary: By forcing public employees to hand over their passports in the workplace, the Communist Party is strengthening its grip on society. Many citizens are questioning the justifications for this control.

title: PSG clinch top spot after 3-0 win over Marseille: 'We dedicate this victory to the fans'
summary: After Monaco lost their first match of the season, Paris Saint-Germain, who beat Marseille at the Stade Velodrome on Sunday, moved into the top spot of Ligue 1.

title: 'Republican voters remain overwhelmingly committed to Trump, whatever he may say or do'
summary: Columnist Alain Frachon analyses the mystery of the trust Trump's voters place in him, despite the former president's radical and and increasingly erratic comments.

title: Puff Daddy in Le Monde: From bling-bling media personality to inmate 37 452-054
summary: American businessman Sean Combs, accused of multiple rapes, is the target of a federal investigation into potential sex trafficking. It was already against a backdrop of violence that the rapper and producer first appeared in Le Monde, on January 1, 1997.

title: Uruguay is gripped by cocaine trafficking amid elections
summary: As the gateway to Europe for the new cocaine routes, Montevideo, once known for its tranquillity, is now gripped by drug-related crime. This issue is at the heart of the campaign in Sunday's general elections.

title: In Venezuela, Nicolas Maduro drops new officials and tightens up his team
summary: Three months after Maduro's disputed re-election, a former oil minister was arrested, while the European Union awarded the Sakharov Prize to opponents Maria Corina Machado and Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia.

title: 2024 US elections: How Viktor Orban is shaping Donald Trump's campaign
summary: Hungary's nationalist prime minister has spent tens of millions of euros to successfully influence the Republican candidate's campaign.

title: Dominique Méda: 'A small, affordable and sustainable electric car can be made in France, enabling a just transition'
summary: The crisis facing European car manufacturers has more to do with their inability to produce a car that meets consumer needs than with the standards imposed by the EU, observed the philosopher and sociologist in her column.

title: Lithuania votes in runoff election amid security concerns about Russia, center-left opposition leading
summary: The vote is likely to replace the ruling conservatives with a center-left coalition, while leaving intact the NATO and EU member's strong support for Ukraine.

title: Watchmakers in Switzerland cut back on working hours
summary: Falling sales of luxury watches, particularly in China, are forcing Swiss watchmakers to reduce working hours in their workshops.

title: Is the 'America first' mission accomplished?
summary: Over the past four years, the Biden administration has cemented Trump's shift toward protectionism, focusing on relocating strategic industries amid Chinese competition and working-class discontent. The results are mixed.

title: Israel's retaliatory strikes against Iran: A new type of deterrence designed to avoid escalation
summary: The Israeli army bombed Iranian military sites on Saturday morning, without targeting nuclear or oil installations. This response to Iran's October 1 strikes had been weeks in the making.

title: Trump's New York rally draws criticism as he ramps up Harris attacks with wife Melania present
summary: Donald Trump accused Kamala Harris on Sunday of destroying the United States. Several other speakers at the 20,000-seat Madison Square Garden venue drew cheers with their barbs against Harris, Puerto Rico and Latinos in the final stretch of one of America's closest-ever White House races.

title: Ocean, oysters and marshes: A walk along Oléron
summary: A hiking trail created in 2023 will take you around the Charente-Maritime island. Spend five days exploring beaches, vineyards and forests, while watching the tides and the greylag geese.

title: Gérard Depardieu heads to court for sexual assault trial
summary: The French actor plans to attend his trial in which he is facing charges of sexual assault on two women on a film set in 2021.

title: South of Beirut, Sainte-Thérèse hospital under constant threat from Israeli bombs
summary: Located close to Hezbollah installations, the plant, which has been repeatedly hit by explosions, is now operating at a very low level.

title: Japan PM under pressure after debacle election
summary: On Monday, the LDP's election committee chief, former premier Junichiro Koizumi's son Shinjiro Koizumi, resigned. The most likely next step is that Ishiba will now seek to head a minority government, with the divided opposition seen as probably incapable of forming a coalition of their own, analysts said.

title: Uruguay's left, center-right candidates to duel in presidential runoff next month
summary: Yamandu Orsi and Alvaro Delgado beat out nine other candidates bidding to replace Lacalle Pou, who has a 50% approval rating but is barred from seeking a second consecutive five-year term.

title: Art gallery Monopoly in Paris: Between market challenges and urban changes
summary: Both American and French industry heavyweights are choosing to relocate to more attractive neighborhoods, such as Avenue Matignon and Palais-Royal, or even to the suburbs.

title: Should you say 'I love you' when you don't mean it?
summary: These three words act like a pact between the one who utters them and the one who receives them – sometimes at the cost of embarrassment, lies or even manipulation. In the end, could all declarations of love be a misunderstanding?

title: How the Chinese mafia kidnaps Africans to swindle Westerners
summary: Africans are being trapped by cartels, lured by the promise of lucrative customer service contracts, and forced into laboring in centers devoted to cyberfraud across Myanmar, Laos and Cambodia.

title: US presidential election: Trump takes revenge on New York at Madison Square Garden
summary: The Republican candidate held a rally in the legendary Manhattan venue on Sunday. With his guests, some of whom made overtly racist remarks, he delivered his aggressive rhetoric, escalating his attacks on the Democratic candidate, Kamala Harris.

title: The wild years of the Fondation Cartier, a private patronage pioneer
summary: On October 20, 1984, Maison Cartier inaugurated a site dedicated to contemporary art in Jouy-en-Josas, southwest of Paris. Through a series of ground-breaking exhibitions, the Fondation Cartier shone the spotlight on promising unknown and established artists.

title: Fanny Lauby, political scientist: 'Trump's plan to deport undocumented immigrants would deal a fatal blow to the US economy'
summary: Fanny Lauby, political scientist and associate professor of political science at Montclair State University in New Jersey, answered readers' questions about the importance of immigration in the electorate and in the platforms of the two White House candidates.

title: Israel continues assault on ravaged northern Gaza Strip
summary: In just over three weeks, the Israeli army has killed hundreds of Palestinians in the enclave's far north, as it seeks to empty the area of its inhabitants. Some 60,000 people were driven from their homes. Those who remain are abandoned to their fate.

title: France's hijab bans in sports is 'discriminatory,' say UN experts
summary: The country notably invoked its strict rules on secularism to ban its athletes from wearing religious symbols, including the hijab, during the Paris 2024 Olympics.
